• Climate: Lemons thrive in tropical and subtropical climates. The ideal temperature range is 25°C–30°C, with protection from frost.
• Soil: Well-drained sandy loam or clay loam soils with good organic matter content are ideal. Soil pH should range between 5.5–7.5.
• Planting Guidelines: - Use healthy, disease-free saplings from a trusted nursery. - Recommended spacing: 4m x 4m for normal planting or 6m x 6m for high-density planting. - Plant during the monsoon or early spring season.
• Varieties: Popular lemon varieties include: - Eureka (seedless variety). - Lisbon (drought-tolerant variety). - Kagzi (Indian lime). - Meyer (sweet and cold-tolerant variety).
• Irrigation: - Young plants require frequent watering, especially during dry periods. - Drip irrigation is ideal for efficient water management. - Avoid waterlogging to prevent root rot.
• Fertilization Schedule: - Apply 10–15 kg of organic manure per tree annually. - Use NPK fertilizers based on soil testing. A typical dose is 200g Nitrogen, 150g Phosphorus, and 150g Potassium per tree per year. - Supplement with micronutrients like Zinc and Iron to enhance growth.
• Training and Pruning: - Train plants to a single stem during the initial years. - Prune dead, diseased, or overcrowded branches regularly to maintain airflow and light penetration.
• Pests and Diseases: - Common pests: Citrus psyllid, leaf miners, and aphids. Use organic or chemical controls as needed. - Common diseases: Citrus canker, gummosis, and greening disease. Ensure proper drainage and apply preventive fungicides.
• Harvesting: - Lemons are ready for harvest 6–8 months after flowering. - Harvest when fruits are firm, fully grown, and have turned yellow or light green.
• Post-Harvest Management: - Store lemons in a cool, well-ventilated place to maintain freshness. - For longer storage, use refrigeration at 10°C–13°C with 85% humidity.
• Additional Tips: - Apply mulch around the base to conserve soil moisture and suppress weeds. - Install windbreaks to protect against strong winds. - Regularly monitor for signs of nutrient deficiencies or pest infestations.
Lemon cultivation is a rewarding venture with consistent demand in the fresh fruit market, juice production, and culinary uses. With proper management practices, lemon farming can be both sustainable and profitable.
